8    |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **

11   |  **		Jens Hamisch, jens@Strawberry.COM			     **
12   |  ** 									     **
13   |  **   Description:	Displays what changes a modulefile will make to the  **
14   |  **			environment including any conflics or prerequisits.  **
15   |  ** 									     **
16   |  **   Exports:		ModuleCmd_Display				     **
17   |  ** 									     **
18   |  **   Notes:								     **

31   | static void *UseId[] = { &UseId, Id };
32   |

55   | /** not applicable **/
56   | 
57   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
58   | /** 				    LOCAL DATA				     **/
59   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
60   | 
61   | char local_line[] =
62   |     "-------------------------------------------------------------------";
63   | static	char	module_name[] = __FILE__;
64   | 
65   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
66   | /**				    PROTOTYPES				     **/
67   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
68   | 
69   | /** not applicable **/
70   | 
71   | 
72   | /*++++
73   |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
74   |  ** 									     **
75   |  **   Function:		ModuleCmd_Display				     **
76   |  ** 									     **
77   |  **   Description:	Execution of the module-command 'display'	     **
78   |  **			Display every change a module 'load' would apply to  **
79   |  **			the environment					     **
80   |  ** 									     **
81   |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
82   |  ** 									     **
83   |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	*interp		Attached Tcl Interp. **
84   |  **			char 		*argv[]		Argument list	     **
85   |  ** 									     **
86   |  **   Result:		int	TCL_ERROR	Failure			     **
87   |  **				TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
88   |  ** 									     **
89   |  **   Attached Globals:	g_specified_module	The module name from the     **
90   |  **						command line.		     **
91   |  **   			g_flags		These are set up accordingly before  **
92   |  **					this function is called in order to  **
93   |  **					control everything		     **
94   |  **			g_current_module	The module which is handled  **
95   |  **						by the current command	     **
96   |  ** 									     **
97   |  ** ************************************************************************ **
98   |  ++++*/
99   | 
100  | int ModuleCmd_Display(	Tcl_Interp	*interp,
101  | 			int		 argc,
102  |                   	char		*argv[])
103  | {
104  |     Tcl_Interp	*disp_interp;
105  |     Tcl_DString	 cmdbuf;
106  |     int		 i,
107  |     		 result;
108  |     char	 modulefile[ MOD_BUFSIZE];
109  |     char	 modulename[ MOD_BUFSIZE];
110  |     
111  |     /**
112  |      **  Initialize the command buffer and set up the modules flag to 'display
113  |      **  only'
114  |      **/
115  |     Tcl_DStringInit( &cmdbuf);
116  |     g_flags |= M_DISPLAY;
117  | 
118  |     /**
119  |      **  Handle each passed module file. Create a Tcl interpreter for each 
120  |      **  module file to be handled and initialize it with custom module commands
121  |      **/
122  | 
123  |     for(i=0; i<argc && argv[i]; i++) {
124  |         /**
125  |          ** Set the name of the module specified on the command line
126  |          **/
127  | 
128  |         g_specified_module = argv[i];
129  | 
130  | 	disp_interp = Tcl_CreateInterp();
131  | 	if( TCL_OK != (result = Module_Init( disp_interp))) {
132  | 	    Tcl_DeleteInterp( disp_interp);
133  | 	    return( result);		/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
134  | 	}
135  | 
136  | 	/**
137  | 	 **  locate the filename related to the passed module
138  | 	 **/
139  | 
140  | 	if( Locate_ModuleFile(disp_interp, argv[i], modulename, modulefile) == 
141  |             TCL_ERROR) {
142  | 	    Tcl_DeleteInterp( disp_interp);
143  | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_LOCATE, LOC, argv[i], NULL)) 
144  | 		break;
145  | 	    else
146  | 		continue;
147  | 	}
148  | 
149  | 	/**
150  | 	 **  Print out everything that would happen if the module file were
151  | 	 **  executed ...
152  | 	 **/
153  | 
154  |         g_current_module = modulename;
155  | 
156  |         fprintf( stderr, "%s\n",local_line);
157  | 	fprintf( stderr, "%s:\n\n", modulefile);
158  | 
159  | 	result = CallModuleProcedure( disp_interp, &cmdbuf, modulefile, 
160  | 	    "ModulesDisplay", 0);
161  | 
162  |         fprintf( stderr, "%s\n",local_line);
163  | 
164  | 	/**
165  | 	 **  Remove the Tcl interpreter that has been used for printing ...
166  | 	 **/
167  | 
168  | 	Tcl_DeleteInterp( disp_interp);
169  | 
170  |     } /** for **/
171  | 
172  |     /**
173  |      **  Leave the 'display only mode', free up what has been used and return
174  |      **/
175  | 
176  |     g_flags &= ~M_DISPLAY;
177  |     fprintf( stderr, "\n");
178  | 
179  |     Tcl_DStringFree( &cmdbuf);
180  | 
181  |     return( TCL_OK);
182  | 
183  | } /** End of 'ModuleCmd_Display' **/
184  |
